Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Synergy of size exclusion and Donnan effect

Other Information.Additional Info: 97.6% rejection. Rejection enhanced at elevated pH values due to more negative charges on TC and membrane. High rejection observed over wide concentration range.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Donnan effect, combined with size exclusion

Other Information.Additional Info: 90.3% rejection. Negatively charged molecule, rejected despite MW being lower than membrane MWCO.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Combination of size exclusion and other effects (less Donnan due to neutral charge)
Size exclusion outperformed electrostatic attraction; hydrophobic interaction

Other Information.Additional Info: 97.6% rejection. Positively charged molecule with high MW (837 Da) and high hydrophobicity (LogKow = 2.75). Rejection aided by low hydrophobic attraction with hydrophilic membrane.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Less effective rejection due to positive charge, some hydrophobic interaction

Other Information.Additional Info: 59.9% rejection. Positively charged molecule with low MW (290 Da) and low hydrophobicity (LogKow = 0.73).

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion (due to complex formation with TC)

Other Information.Test Conditions: Combined with 0.01 mM antibiotics, 0.3 mM concentration
Other Information.Additional Info: 96.8% rejection in combined contaminants. Forms larger complexes with TC.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion (due to complex formation with TC)

Other Information.Test Conditions: Combined with 0.01 mM antibiotics, 0.3 mM concentration
Other Information.Additional Info: 91.7% rejection in combined contaminants. Forms larger complexes with TC.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion (due to complex formation with TC)

Other Information.Test Conditions: Combined with 0.01 mM antibiotics, 0.3 mM concentration
Other Information.Additional Info: 89.0% rejection in combined contaminants. Forms larger complexes with TC.

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on pore aperture (size exclusion), Donnan effect (electrostatic repulsion), and hydrophobic effect (hydrophobic interaction)

Experimental Validation.Method: Cross-flow filtration, MWCO determination, Zeta potential measurements, Pressure-dependent tests
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Water permeability: 76.2 L h-1 m-2 bar-1; MWCO: 343 Da; Antibiotics rejection: 60.0%–97.6%; TC removal: 99.6% (with heavy metals); Pb2+ removal: 96.8%; Cu2+ removal: 91.7%; Ni2+ removal: 89.0%; TOC removal: 71.1%; UV254 removal: 61.9%; COD removal: 77.0%; Flux recovery: 100% after 3 cycles (BSA) and 10 cycles (wastewater).

Other Information.Additional Info: Incorporated into porous PVDF matrix. Exhibits good flexibility and tolerance to bending/buckling. Enhanced hydrophilicity (WCA: 51.3°). Increased negative charge density (Zeta potential: -36.6 mV at pH 7). Possesses exceptional electrocatalytic self-cleaning performance due to generation of •OH and •O2− free radicals. Demonstrates high acid and alkali resistance (negligible metal leaching). Breaks permeability-rejection trade-off of conventional NF membranes.
